MoonTrek Legend

  • Geographical Features

July 16th, 1969

Landing Site

    The first manned spacecraft landing on the Moon was at 3:17 p.m. EST (20:17:40 UTC) on July 20, 1969, when the Apollo 11 Lunar Module, the Eagle, landed in Mare Tranquillitatis, located at 0°4'5"N latitude, 23°42'28"E longitude.

Mission Objective

    The mission plan of Apollo 11 was to land two men on the lunar surface and return them safely to Earth. The launch took place at Kennedy Space Center Launch Complex 39A on July 16, 1969, at 08:32 a.m. EST. The spacecraft carried a crew of three: Mission Commander Neil Armstrong, Command Module Pilot Michael Collins, and Lunar Module Pilot Edwin E. Aldrin Jr.
Link To Apollo 14 NASA Page

January 31st, 1971

Landing Site

    The landing site is located in a broad, shallow valley between radial ridges of the Fra Mauro Formation and approximately 500 kilometers from the edge of the Imbrium Basin. The major crater Copernicus lies 360 kilometers to the north, and bright ray material that emanates from Copernicus Crater covers much of the landing site region.

Mission Objective

    The primary objectives of this mission were to explore the Fra Mauro region centered around deployment of the Apollo Lunar Surface Scientific Experiments Package, or ALSEP; lunar field geology investigations; collection of surface material samples for return to Earth
Link To Apollo 14 NASA Page

Tycho Crater

Age

    It's thought that some of the samples at the Apollo 17 landing site originated at the Tycho impact site. These samples are impact melt glass, and radiometric age dating tells us that they formed 108 million years ago.

Importance

    Tycho is also of great scientific interest because it is so well preserved, it is a great place to study the mechanics of how an impact crater forms. Tycho's central peak is thought to be material that has rebounded back up after being compressed in the impact, and though it's a peak now, it originated at greater depth than any other portion of the crater.
Link To Tycho Crater NASA Page

Copernicus Crater

Importance

    Copernicus crater played a key role as pioneering lunar geologists Gene Shoemaker and Robert Hackman unraveled the basic stratigraphy of the Moon fifty years ago. Stratigraphy is the science of determining relative ages of geologic materials by observing overlapping relationships between different geologic units.
Link To Copernicus Crater

Information

    Montes Apenninus is home to the Moon’s tallest mountain Mons Huygens, which soars 5.5 km high, though its not the highest point on the Moon. On the east end of the mountain range lies the mountain Mons Hadley Delta, near which NASA’s historical Apollo 15 mission landed. From Apollo 15 rock samples, we know that the impact that formed Imbrium basin happened several hundred million years before the volcanic eruptions that filled the basin.
Link To Montes Appenius NASA Page
